Israel is the only country in the region ranked "Free" by [[Freedom House]] based on the level of civil liberties and political rights; the "Palestinian Authority-Administered Territories" was ranked "Not Free."{{cite quick |web |title=Palestinian Authority-Administered Territories |publisher=Freedom House |year=2010 |url=http://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2010/palestinian-authority-administered-territories |work=Freedom in the World |accessdate=20 March 2012}} In 2012, Israel proper was ranked 92nd according to [[Reporters Without Borders]]' [[Press Freedom Index]] – the highest ranking in the region.{{cite quick |web |url=http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2011-2012,1043.html |publisher=Reporters Without Borders |accessdate=26 April 2012 |date=25 January 2012 |title=Press Freedom Index 2011–2012}} ===Administrative divisions=== {{Main|Districts of Israel}} [[File:Israel districts.png|upright|thumb|[[Districts of Israel]]: [[North District (Israel)|Northern]], [[Haifa District|Haifa]], [[Central District (Israel)|Center]], [[Tel Aviv District|Tel Aviv]], [[Jerusalem District|Jerusalem]], [[Southern District (Israel)|Southern]]]] The State of Israel is divided into six main administrative districts, known as ''mehozot'' (מחוזות; singular: ''mahoz'') – [[Central District (Israel)|Center]], [[Haifa District|Haifa]], [[Jerusalem District|Jerusalem]], [[North District (Israel)|North]], [[Southern District (Israel)|Southern]], and [[Tel Aviv District]]s, as well as the [[Judea and Samaria Area]] in the [[West Bank]]. Districts are further divided into fifteen sub-districts known as ''nafot'' (נפות; singular: ''nafa''), which are themselves partitioned into fifty natural regions.{{cite quick |document |publisher=Central Bureau of Statistics |title=Introduction to the Tables: Geophysical Characteristics |url=http://www.cbs.gov.il/shnaton53/download/st_eng01.doc |format=doc |accessdate=4 September 2007 }} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align: center" |- ! District ! Main city ! Sub-district ! Population |- | '''[[North District, Israel|North]]''' | [[Nazareth]] | [[Yam Kinneret|Kinneret]], [[Safed]], [[Acre, Israel|Acre]], [[Golan Heights|Golan]], [[Jezreel Valley]] | 1,242,100 |- | '''[[Haifa District|Haifa]]''' | [[Haifa]] | [[Haifa]], [[Hadera]] | 880,000 |- | '''[[Center District, Israel|Center]]''' | [[Ramla]] | [[Rishon Lezion]], [[Sharon plain|Sharon]] ([[Netanya]]), [[Petah Tikva]], [[Ramla]], [[Rehovot]] | 1,770,200 |- | '''[[Tel Aviv District|Tel Aviv]]''' | [[Tel Aviv]] | [[Bat Yam]], [[Bnei Brak]], [[Giv'atayim]], [[Holon]], [[Ramat Gan]], [[Tel Aviv]] | 1,227,000 |- | '''[[Jerusalem District|Jerusalem]]''' | [[Jerusalem]] | [[Jerusalem]] | 910,300 |- | '''[[South District (Israel)|South]]''' | [[Beersheba]] | [[Ashkelon]], [[Beersheba]] | 1,053,600 |- | '''[[Judea and Samaria Area|Judea and Samaria]]''' | [[Modi'in Illit]] | [[West Bank]] | 2,592,555{{cite quick |web |url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/we.html |title=CIA world factbook}}
(350,143 Jewish settlers)‏‏{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.israelhayom.co.il/site/newsletter_article.php?id=19600&newsletter=26.07.2012 |title=יותר מ־350 אלף מתנחלים ביו"ש |last= |first= |date=26 July 2012 |work= |publisher=Israel HaYom |language=Hebrew |accessdate=12 August 2012}} |} For statistical purposes, the country is divided into three metropolitan areas: [[Tel Aviv metropolitan area]] (population 3,206,400), [[Haifa metropolitan area]] (population 1,021,000), and [[Beersheba metropolitan area|Beer Sheva metropolitan area]] (population 559,700).{{cite quick |web | url=http://www.cbs.gov.il/shnaton60/st02_16.pdf |format=PDF| title=Localities, Population, and Density | accessdate=30 January 2010 | ref=harv}} Israel's largest municipality, both in population and area,{{cite quick |document |url=http://www.cbs.gov.il/population/new_2010/table3.pdf |publisher=Central Bureau of Statistics |title=Population of localities numbering above 2,000 residents and other rural population |date=30 September 2009 |accessdate=19 February 2010 |format=PDF }} is [[Jerusalem]] with 773,800 residents in an area of 126 square kilometers (49 sq mi) (in 2009). Israeli government statistics on Jerusalem include the population and area of [[East Jerusalem]], which is widely recognized as part of the [[Palestinian territories]] under [[Israeli-occupied territories|Israeli occupation]].{{Harvard citation no brackets|Roberts|1990|p=60}} Although East Jerusalem and the Golan Heights have been brought directly under Israeli law, by acts that amount to annexation, both of these areas continue to be viewed by the international community as occupied, and their status as regards the applicability of international rules is in most respects identical to that of the West Bank and Gaza. [[Tel Aviv]], [[Haifa]], and [[Rishon LeZion]] rank as Israel's next most populous cities, with populations of 393,900, 265,600, and 227,600 respectively. ===Israeli-occupied territories=== {{Main|Israeli-occupied territories}} [[File:Is-wb-gs-gh v3.png|thumb|upright|Map of Israel showing the West Bank, the Gaza Strip, and the Golan Heights]] In 1967, as a result of the [[Six-Day War]], Israel gained control of the [[West Bank]] (Judaea and Samaria), [[East Jerusalem]], the [[Gaza Strip|Gaza strip]] and the [[Golan Heights]]. Israel also took control of the [[Sinai Peninsula]], but returned it to Egypt as part of the 1979 [[Israel–Egypt Peace Treaty]]. Following Israel's capture of these territories, [[Israeli settlement|settlements]] consisting of Israeli citizens were established within each of them. Israel applied civilian law to the [[Golan Heights Law|Golan Heights]] and [[Jerusalem Law|East Jerusalem]], incorporating them into its sovereign territory and granting their inhabitants permanent residency status and the choice to apply for citizenship. In contrast, the West Bank has remained under [[military occupation]], and Palestinians in this area cannot become citizens. The Gaza Strip is independent of Israel with no Israeli military or civilian presence, but Israel continues to maintain control of its airspace and waters. The Gaza Strip and the West Bank are seen by the Palestinians and most of the international community as the site of a [[Proposals for a Palestinian state|future Palestinian state]].{{cite quick |news |title=Solana to Haaretz: New rules of war needed for age of terror |first=Adar |last=Primor |newspaper=Haaretz |date=23 October 2009 |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/solana-to-haaretz-new-rules-of-war-needed-for-age-of-terror-1.5588}}{{cite quick |document |url=http://www.state.gov/secretary/rm/2009a/11/132434.htm |title=United States: "an independent and viable state based on the 1967 lines, with agreed swaps" |date=25 November 2009 |publisher=U.S. Department of State |accessdate=10 April 2010 }} The UN Security Council has declared the annexation of the Golan Heights and East Jerusalem to be "null and void" and continues to view the territories as occupied.{{cite quick |web |url=http://unispal.un.org/UNISPAL.NSF/0/73D6B4C70D1A92B7852560DF0064F101 |title=Resolution 497 (1981) |year=1981 |publisher=United Nations |accessdate=20 March 2012}}{{cite quick |document |url=http://domino.un.org/UNISPAL.NSF/0/dde590c6ff232007852560df0065fddb?OpenDocument |title=East Jerusalem: UNSC Res. 478 |year=1980 |publisher=UN |accessdate=10 April 2010 }} The [[International Court of Justice]], principal judicial organ of the United Nations, asserted, in its [[International law and the Arab–Israeli conflict#Ruling of the ICJ|2004 advisory opinion]] on the legality of the construction of the [[Israeli West Bank barrier]], that the lands captured by Israel in the Six-Day War, including East Jerusalem, are occupied territory.{{cite quick |document |title=Arabs will ask UN to seek razing of Israeli wall |publisher=MSNBC |date=9 July 2004 |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/5400559/ |accessdate=7 July 2010 }} The status of East Jerusalem in any future peace settlement has at times been a difficult hurdle in negotiations between Israeli governments and representatives of the Palestinians, as Israel views it as its sovereign territory, as well as part of its capital. Most negotiations relating to the territories have been on the basis of [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 242]], which emphasises "the inadmissibility of the acquisition of territory by war", and calls on Israel to withdraw from occupied territories in return for normalization of relations with Arab states, a principle known as "[[Land for peace]]".{{cite quick |document |title=Olmert: Willing to trade land for peace |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |date =16 December 2006 |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3340641,00.html |accessdate=26 September 2007 }}{{cite quick |news |title=Syria ready to discuss land for peace |newspaper=The Jerusalem Post |date=12 June 2007 |url=http://www.jpost.com/Israel/Article.aspx?id=64667 |accessdate=20 March 2012}}{{cite quick |news |title=Egypt: Israel must accept the land-for-peace formula |newspaper=The Jerusalem Post |date=15 March 2007 |url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=54876 |accessdate=20 March 2012}} The West Bank was annexed by Jordan in 1948, following the Arab rejection of the UN decision to create two states in Palestine. Only Britain recognized this annexation and Jordan has since [[Israel–Jordan peace treaty#cite note-0|ceded]] its claim to the territory to the [[Palestine Liberation Organization|PLO]]. The West Bank was occupied by Israel in 1967 during the Six-Day War. The population are mainly [[Arab people|Arab]] [[Palestinian people|Palestinians]], including [[Palestinian refugee|refugees]] of the [[1948 Arab–Israeli War|1948 Arab-Israeli War]].{{cite quick |document |title=UNRWA in Figures: Figures as of 30 June 2009 |publisher=United Nations |month=June | year=2009 |url=http://www.unrwa.org/userfiles/uif-june09.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=27 September 2007 }} From their occupation in 1967 until 1993, the Palestinians living in these territories were under [[Coordinator of Government Activities in the Territories|Israeli military administration]]. Since the [[Israel – Palestine Liberation Organization letters of recognition|Israel–PLO letters of recognition]], most of the [[Demographics of the Palestinian territories|Palestinian population]] and [[List of cities in Palestinian Authority areas|cities]] have been under the internal jurisdiction of the [[Palestinian National Authority|Palestinian Authority]], and only partial Israeli military control, although Israel has on several occasions redeployed its [[Israel Defense Forces|troops]] and reinstated full military administration during periods of unrest. In response to increasing attacks as part of the [[Second Intifada]], the Israeli government started to construct the Israeli West Bank barrier.{{cite quick |document | url=http://www.securityfence.mod.gov.il/Pages/ENG/questions.htm | title=Questions and Answers | accessdate=17 April 2007 | date=22 February 2004 | work=Israel’s Security Fence | publisher=The State of Israel | ref=harv}} When completed, approximately 13% of the Barrier will be constructed on the Green Line or in Israel with 87% inside the West Bank.{{cite quick |web|author=United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees |url=http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/docid/4875de625.html |title=[accessed 20 June 2010 |publisher=Unhcr.org |accessdate=29 September 2010}}{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.btselem.org/publications/summaries/200512_under_the_guise_of_security |title=Under the Guise of Security: Routing the Separation Barrier to Enable Israeli Settlement Expansion in the West Bank |accessdate=20 March 2012 |month=December |year=2005 |work=Publications |publisher=[[B'Tselem]]}} The Gaza Strip was [[Occupation of the Gaza Strip by Egypt|occupied by Egypt from 1948 to 1967]] and then by Israel after 1967. In 2005, as part of [[Israel's unilateral disengagement plan]], Israel removed all of its settlers and forces from the territory. Israel does not consider the Gaza Strip to be occupied territory and declared it a "foreign territory". That view has been disputed by numerous international humanitarian organizations and various bodies of the United Nations.{{cite quick |web |url=http://unispal.un.org/UNISPAL.NSF/0/F0B7D1A3A8E7CF1985257552004F640E |title=Situation Report on the Humanitarian Situation in the Gaza Strip |publisher=Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs |date=23 January 2009}}{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.icrc.org/eng/resources/documents/report/palestine-report-131207.htm |title=The occupied Palestinian territories: Dignity Denied |publisher=International Committee of the Red Cross |date=13 December 2007}}{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.hrw.org/world-report-2006/israeloccupied-palestinian-territories-opt |title=Israel/Occupied Palestinian Territories (OPT) |work=Country Summary |publisher=Human Rights Watch |month=January |year=2006}}{{cite quick |web |url=http://www2.ohchr.org/english/bodies/hrcouncil/specialsession/9/docs/unffmgc_report.pdf |title=Human Rights in Palestine and Other Occupied Arab Territories: Report of the United Nations Fact Finding Mission on the Gaza Conflict |publisher=United Nations Human Rights Council |date=15 September 2009 |page=85}}{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.amnesty.org/en/library/asset/MDE15/093/2006/en/9dc8177a-d3cf-11dd-8743-d305bea2b2c7/mde150932006en.html |title=Israel/Occupied Territories: Road to nowhere |publisher=Amnesty International |date=1 December 2006}} Following June 2007, when [[Governance of the Gaza Strip|Hamas assumed power in the Gaza Strip]], Israel tightened its control of the Gaza crossings along its border, as well as by sea and air, and prevented persons from entering and exiting the area except for isolated cases it deemed humanitarian.{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.btselem.org/gaza_strip/gaza_status |title=The scope of Israeli control in the Gaza Strip |publisher=B'Tselem |accessdate=20 March 2012}} Gaza has a border with Egypt and an agreement between Israel, the European Union and the [[Palestinian National Authority|PA]] governed how border crossing would take place (it was monitored by European observers).{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.eubam-rafah.eu/portal/files/aprc.pdf |title=Agreed Principles for Rafah Crossing |publisher=[[European Union Border Assistance Mission Rafah]]}} Egypt adhered to this agreement under Mubarak and prevented access to Gaza until April 2011 when it announced it was opening its border with Gaza. ===Foreign relations=== {{Main|Foreign relations of Israel}} [[File:Hutz.JPG|thumb|The [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Israel)|Israeli Foreign Ministry]] in [[Jerusalem]].]] Israel maintains diplomatic relations with 157 countries and has 100 [[diplomatic mission]]s around the world.{{cite quick |document|url=http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/About%20the%20Ministry/Diplomatic%20missions/Israel-s%20Diplomatic%20Missions%20Abroad |publisher=Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs |accessdate=13 March 2009|date=12 July 2006 |title=Israel's Diplomatic Missions Abroad: Status of Relations}} Only three members of the [[Arab League]] have normalized relations with Israel: Egypt and Jordan signed peace treaties in [[Israel–Egypt Peace Treaty|1979]] and [[Israel–Jordan Treaty of Peace|1994]], respectively, and Mauritania opted for full diplomatic relations with Israel in 1999. Despite the peace treaty between Israel and Egypt, Israel is still widely considered an enemy country among Egyptians."Massive Israel protests hit universities" (Egyptian Mail, 16 March 2010) "According to most Egyptians, almost 31 years after a peace treaty was signed between Egypt and Israel, having normal ties between the two countries is still a potent accusation and Israel is largely considered to be an enemy country" Under Israeli law, Lebanon, Syria, Saudi Arabia, Iraq, and Yemen are enemy countries{{cite quick |document |url=http://www.justice.gov.il/NR/rdonlyres/129A5B6A-20D6-4C3B-9785-1C6B6763394A/0/CRCengfull.pdf |publisher=Israel Ministry of Justice |format=PDF |title=Initial Periodic Report of the State of Israel Concerning the Implementation of the Convention of the Rights of the Child (CRC) |accessdate=9 August 2007 |month=February |year=2001 |pages=147 (173 using pdf numbering) }} and Israeli citizens may not visit them without permission from the [[Ministry of Interior (Israel)|Ministry of the Interior]].{{he icon}} {{cite quick |document |url=http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFAHeb/MFAArchive/2004/horaot+din+israeli0304.htm |publisher=Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs |title=הוראות הדין הישראלי |year=2004 |accessdate=9 August 2007 }} The [[Soviet Union]] and the United States were the first two countries to recognize the State of Israel, having declared recognition roughly simultaneously. The United States may regard Israel as its primary ally in the Middle East, based on "common democratic values, religious affinities, and security interests".{{cite quick |document|url=http://www.dtic.mil/cgi-bin/GetTRDoc?AD=ADA470003&Location=U2&doc=GetTRDoc.pdf|title=Israel: Background and Relations with the United States Updated|publisher=Defense Technical Information Center|accessdate=19 October 2009}} The United States has provided $68 billion in military assistance and $32 billion in grants to Israel since 1967, under the [[Foreign Assistance Act]] (period beginning 1962),{{cite quick |web |url=http://pdf.usaid.gov/pdf_docs/PNADT555.pdf |title=U.S. Overseas Loans and Grants}} more than any other country for that period until 2003.{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.census.gov/compendia/statab/2012/tables/12s1297.pdf |title=U.S. Government Foreign Grants and Credits by Type and Country: 2000 to 2010}}{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.census.gov/compendia/statab/cats/foreign_commerce_aid/foreign_aid.html |title=Foreign Aid}} Their bilateral relations are multidimensional and the United States is the principal proponent of the Arab-Israeli [[Peace process in the Israeli–Palestinian conflict|peace process]]. The United States and Israeli views differ on some issues, such as the Golan Heights, Jerusalem, and settlements.{{cite quick |web |url=http://assets.opencrs.com/rpts/RL33476_20110214.pdf |title=Israel: Background and U.S. Relations |format=PDF |publisher=Congressional Research Service |last=Addis |first=Casey L. |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=20 March 2012}} India established full diplomatic ties with Israel in 1992 and has fostered a strong military, technological and cultural partnership with the country since then.{{cite quick |web |url=http://pakistanyouthmovement.com/Research-Reports/India%20Israel%20Ties.pdf |publisher=Jerusalem Institute for Western Defense |last=Kumar |first=Dinesh |title=India and Israel: Dawn of a New Era |accessdate=19 March 2012}} According to an international opinion survey conducted in 2009 on behalf of the Israeli Foreign Ministry, India is the most pro-Israel country in the world.{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3696887,00.html |title=From India with love |newspaper=Ynetnews |last=Eichner |first=Itamar |date=4 March 2009 |accessdate=20 March 2012}}{{cite quick |news |title=Nitin Gadkari to visit Israel tomorrow |url=http://news.worldsnap.com/city/delhi/nitin-gadkari-to-visit-israel-tomorrow-97059.html |newspaper=World Snap |date=13 December 2010 |accessdate=1 October 2012}} India is the largest customer of Israeli military equipment and Israel is the second-largest military partner of India after the Russian Federation.{{cite quick |news |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-01-19/india/28119010_1_largest-ever-defence-deal-second-largest-defence-supplier-sensitive-technology-control-requirements |title=India to hold wide-ranging strategic talks with US, Israel |newspaper=The Times of India |date=19 January 2010 |accessdate=20 March 2012}} India is also the third-largest Asian economic partner of Israel{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.indembassy.co.il/Bilateral%20Trade%20Relations.htm |title=Overview of India-Israel Bilateral Trade and Economic Relations}} and the two countries enjoy extensive [[space technology]] ties.{{cite quick |web |last=Koshy |first=Ninan |url=http://www.fpif.org/articles/india_and_israel_eye_iran |title=India and Israel Eye Iran |publisher=Foreign Policy In Focus |accessdate=20 March 2012}}{{cite quick |news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/asiapcf/03/21/india.satellite/index.html?iref=mpstoryview |title=India to launch Israel-backed satellite |publisher=CNN |date=21 March 2009 |accessdate=1 June 2010}} India became the top source market for Israel from Asia in 2010 with 41,000 tourist arrivals in that year.{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.eturbonews.com/21376/india-replaces-korea-top-asian-market-israel |title=India replaces Korea as top Asian market for Israel}} [[Germany|Germany's]] strong ties with Israel include cooperation on scientific and educational endeavors and the two states remain strong economic and military partners.{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.germany.info/relaunch/info/archives/background/israel.html |title=Germany and Israel |work=Background Papers |publisher=German Embassy |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20070927023555/http://www.germany.info/relaunch/info/archives/background/israel.html |archivedate=27 September 2007 |accessdate=23 September 2007}}{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article3564572.ece |title=Israel welcomes new Germany to a celebration of its 60th birthday |work=The Times |location=London |accessdate=13 March 2009 | first=Roger | last=Boyes | date=17 March 2008 }} Under the reparations agreement, {{As of|2007|lc=yes}} Germany had paid 25 billion euros in reparations to the Israeli state and individual Israeli holocaust survivors.{{cite quick |web|url=http://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/row/RL33808.pdf |title=Congressional Research Service: Germany’s Relations with Israel: Background and Implications for German Middle East Policy, Jan 19, 2007. (page CRS-2) |format=PDF |accessdate=29 September 2010}} The UK has kept full diplomatic relations with Israel since its formation having had two visits from heads of state in 2007. Relations between the two countries were also made stronger by former prime minister [[Tony Blair]]'s efforts for a two state resolution. The UK is seen as having a "natural" relationship with Israel on account of the [[British Mandate for Palestine]].{{cite quick |web |url=http://ukinisrael.fco.gov.uk/en/about-us/working-with-israel/uk-israel-relations/bilateral-relations |publisher=Foreign and Commonwealth Office |title=The bilateral relationship |work=UK in Israel |accessdate=20 March 2012}} [[Iran–Israel relations|Iran]] had diplomatic relations with Israel under the [[Pahlavi dynasty]]{{Harvard citation no brackets|Abadi|2004|pp=37–39, 47}} but withdrew its recognition of Israel during the [[Islamic Revolution]].{{Harvard citation no brackets|Abadi|2004|pp=47–49}} Although Turkey and Israel did not establish full diplomatic relations until 1991,{{Harvard citation no brackets|Abadi|2004|p=3}}. "However, it was not until 1991 that the two countries established full diplomatic relations." Turkey has cooperated with the State since its recognition of Israel in 1949. Turkey's ties to the other Muslim-majority nations in the region have at times resulted in pressure from Arab and Muslim states to temper its relationship with Israel.{{Harvard citation no brackets|Abadi|2004|pp=4–6}} Relations between Turkey and Israel took a downturn after the [[Gaza War]] and Israel's raid of the [[Gaza flotilla raid|Gaza flotilla]].{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/05/31/AR2010053102860.html |title=Turkey urges U.N. Security Council to condemn Israeli attack on aid flotilla |author=Colum Lynch |work=Washington Post |date=30 May 2010 |accessdate=23 June 2010}} [[IHH (Turkish NGO)|IHH]], which organized the flotilla, is a Turkish charity that some believe has ties to [[Hamas]] and [[Al-Qaeda]].{{cite quick |news |title=Israel Navy commandos: Gaza flotilla activists tried to lynch us |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/israel-navy-commandos-gaza-flotilla-activists-tried-to-lynch-us-1.293089 |newspaper=Haaretz |date=31 May 2010 |accessdate=18 October 2012}}{{cite quick |news|author=AP |url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2010/05/30/reports-israeli-ships-attack-aid-flotilla-dead/ |title=Israeli Officials Claim Aid Flotilla Had Ties to Al Qaeda, PM Gives Military 'Full Support' |publisher=Fox News |date=7 April 2010 |accessdate=29 September 2010}}{{cite quick |news |title=Israel tries to limit diplomatic damage from raid |first=Mark |last=Lavie |first2=Karin |last2=Laub |first3=Selcan |last3=Hacaoglu |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2010/jun/2/israel-tries-limit-diplomatic-damage-raid/?page=all |agency=Associated Press |newspaper=The Washington Times |location=Jerusalem |date=2 June 2010 |accessdate=26 April 2012}}{{cite quick |news |title=IDF: Five Gaza flotilla activists linked to Hamas, Al-Qaida |first=Anshel |last=Pfeffer |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/idf-five-gaza-flotilla-activists-linked-to-hamas-al-qaida-1.294546 |newspaper=Haaretz |date=6 June 2010 |accessdate=26 April 2012}} Relation between Israel and Greece have improved since 1995 due to the decline of Israeli-Turkish relations.{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-11556442 |title=Israel woos Greece after rift with Turkey |newspaper=BBC News |date=16 October 2010}} The two countries have a defence cooperation agreement and in 2010, the [[Israeli Air Force]] hosted Greece’s [[Hellenic Air Force]] in a joint exercise at the [[Ovda Airport|Uvda base]]. The joint Cyprus-Israel oil and gas explorations centered on the [[Leviathan gas field]] are also an important factor for Greece, given its strong links with [[Cyprus]].{{cite quick |news |title=Turkey, Greece discuss exploration off Cyprus |agency=Associated Press |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/middle-east/turkey-greece-discuss-exploration-off-cyprus-1.386864 |newspaper=Haaretz |date=26 September 2011 |accessdate=1 January 2012}} Israel is the second largest importer of Greek products in the Middle East.{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.rieas.gr/research-areas/greek-studies/115.html |title=An Outline of Greek-Israeli Strategic Relations |last1=Nomikos |first1=John M. |last2=Michaletos |first2=Ioannis |publisher=Research Institute for European and American Studies |accessdate=26 April 2012}} In 2010, the [[Greek Prime minister]] [[George Papandreou (junior)|George Papandreou]] made an official visit to Israel after many years, in order to improve [[bilateral relations]] between the two countries.{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/Government/Speeches+by+Israeli+leaders/2010/PM_Netanyahu_welcomes_Greek_PM_Papandreou_22-Jul-2010 |title=PM Netanyahu welcomes Greek PM Papandreou |publisher=Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs |date=22 July 2010}} Israel and Cyprus have a number of bilateral agreements and many official visits have taken place between the two countries. The countries have ties on energy, agricultural, military and tourism matters. The prospects of joint exploitation of oil and gas fields off Cyprus, as well as cooperation in the world's longest sub-sea electric power cable has strengthened relations between the countries.{{cite quick |web|title=The Cyprus connection|url=http://www.jpost.com/Opinion/Editorials/Article.aspx?id=258207|publisher=The Jerusalem Post|accessdate=16 February 2012}}{{cite quick |web|title=Netanyahu embarks on historic visit to Cyprus|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4190731,00.html|publisher=Ynet|accessdate=16 February 2012}}{{cite quick |news|title=Netanyahu headed to Cyprus to boost cooperation on security, offshore drilling|url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/netanyahu-headed-to-cyprus-to-boost-cooperation-on-security-offshore-drilling-1.408054|newspaper=Haaretz|date=19 January 2012}} Azerbaijan is one of the few majority Muslim countries to develop bilateral strategic and economic relations with Israel. The relationship includes cooperation in trade and security matters and cultural and educational exchanges. Azerbaijan supplies Israel with a substantial amount of its oil needs, and Israel has helped modernize the Armed Forces of Azerbaijan. In the spring of 2012, the two countries reportedly concluded an arms deal worth $1.6 billion.{{cite quick |web | url=http://www.jpost.com/DiplomacyAndPolitics/Article.aspx?id=266803 | title=Foreign minister expected to visit Azerbaijan | publisher=JPost | date=19 April 2012 | accessdate=19 April 2012}}{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/policy-analysis/view/good-relations-between-azerbaijan-and-israel-a-model-for-other-muslim-state |title=Good Relations between Azerbaijan and Israel: A Model for Other Muslim States in Eurasia? |last1=Cagaptay |first1=Soner |last2=Murinson |first2=Alexander |date=30 March 2005 |work= |publisher=Washington Institute for Near East Policy |accessdate=7 May 2012}} In 2005, Azerbaijan was Israel's fifth largest trading partner.{{cite quick |web|last=Bourtman|first=Ilya|title=Israel and Azerbaijan's Furtive Embrace|url=http://www.meforum.org/987/israel-and-azerbaijans-furtive-embrace|publisher=The Middle East Quarterly|accessdate=Summer 2006}}{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.usak.org.tr/dosyalar/dergi/gm3veLfV7Q5rP83jaIV34UObvarinb.pdf |title=The Azerbaijan-Israel Relations: A Non-Diplomatic, But Strategic Partnership |last=Abilov |first=Shamkhal |year=2009 |work=OAKA |publisher=International Strategic Research Organization |accessdate=4 September 2012}} In Africa, Ethiopia is Israel's main and closest ally in the continent due to common political, religious and security interests.{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.economist.com/node/15453225 |title=Iran and Israel in Africa: A search for allies in a hostile world |newspaper=The Economist |date=4 February 2010 |accessdate=20 March 2012}} Israel provides expertise to Ethiopia on irrigation projects and thousands of Ethiopian Jews ([[Beta Israel]]) live in Israel. As a result of the 2009 [[Gaza War]], Mauritania, Qatar, Bolivia, and Venezuela suspended political and economic ties with Israel.{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2009/01/2009116151135307776.html |newspaper=Al Jazeera English |title=Qatar, Mauritania cut Israel ties |accessdate=20 March 2012 |date=17 January 2009}}{{cite quick |document |url=http://www.radiomundial.com.ve/yvke/noticia.php?17621 |publisher=YVKE Mundial Radio |title=Bolivia rompe relaciones diplomáticas con Israel y anuncia demanda por genocidio en Gaza |accessdate=14 April 2010 |date=14 January 2009 |first=Abi |last=Abn |language=Spanish }} ===Military=== {{Main|Israel Defense Forces|Israeli security forces|military operations conducted by the Israel Defense Forces}} {{See also|Israel and weapons of mass destruction}} [[File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - Honor Guard at IDF Headquarters for Outgoing Chief of Staff Lt. Gen. Gabi Ashkenazi.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]] Kirya Compound, [[Tel Aviv]]]] Israel has the highest ratio of defense spending to GDP and as a percentage of the budget of all developed countries.{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.economist.com/node/13808801 |title=Military spending: Arming up |newspaper=The Economist |accessdate=20 March 2012 |date=8 June 2009}}{{cite quick |news |title=Defense budget to grow, education spending to shrink |first=Moti |last=Bassok |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/business/defense-budget-to-grow-education-spending-to-shrink-1.6974 |newspaper=Haaretz |date=30 September 2009 |accessdate=26 April 2012}} The [[Israel Defense Forces]] is the sole military wing of the [[Israeli security forces]], and is headed by its [[Chief of General Staff (Israel)|Chief of General Staff]], the ''Ramatkal'', subordinate to the [[Cabinet of Israel|Cabinet]]. The IDF consist of the [[GOC Army Headquarters|army]], [[Israeli Air Force|air force]] and [[Israeli Navy|navy]]. It was founded during the [[1948 Arab–Israeli War]] by consolidating paramilitary organizations—chiefly the [[Haganah]]—that preceded the establishment of the state.{{cite quick |document|url=http://dover.idf.il/IDF/English/about/History/40s/1948/default.htm |publisher=Israel Defense Forces |accessdate=31 July 2007 |title=History: 1948 |year=2007}} The IDF also draws upon the resources of the [[Military Intelligence Directorate (Israel)|Military Intelligence Directorate]] (''Aman''), which works with the [[Mossad]] and [[Shin Bet|Shabak]].{{Harvard citation no brackets |Henderson |2003 |p=97}} The Israel Defense Forces have been involved in several major wars and border conflicts in its short history, making it one of the most battle-trained armed forces in the world.{{cite quick |document |url=http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/Facts+About+Israel/State/THE+STATE-+Israel+Defense+Forces+-IDF-.htm |publisher=Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs |title=The State: Israel Defense Forces (IDF) |accessdate=9 August 2007 |date=13 March 2009 }}{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/israel/idf.htm |publisher=GlobalSecurity.org |title=Israel Defense Forces |accessdate=16 September 2007 }} Most Israelis are drafted into the military at the age of 18. Men serve three years and women two to three years.{{cite quick |document|url=http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/Facts%20About%20Israel/State/The%20Israel%20Defense%20Forces |title=The Israel Defense Forces |publisher=Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs |accessdate=21 October 2006}} Following mandatory service, Israeli men join the [[Israel Defense Forces#Reserve service|reserve forces]] and usually do up to several weeks of reserve duty every year until their forties. Most women are exempt from reserve duty. [[Arab citizens of Israel]] (except the [[Druze]]) and those engaged in full-time religious studies are exempt from military service, although the [[Tal Law|exemption of yeshiva students]] has been a source of contention in Israeli society for many years.{{Harvard citation no brackets|Stendel|1997|pp=191–192}}{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/cool-law-for-wrong-population-1.220687 |date=16 May 2007 |accessdate=19 March 2012 |title=Cool law, for wrong population |last=Shtrasler |first=Nehemia |newspaper=[[Haaretz]]}} An alternative for those who receive exemptions on various grounds is ''[[Sherut Leumi]]'', or national service, which involves a program of service in hospitals, schools and other social welfare frameworks.{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.nbn.org.il/aliyahpedia/army/585-sherut-leumi-national-service.html |publisher=Nefesh B'Nefesh |accessdate=20 March 2012 |title=Sherut Leumi (National Service)}} As a result of its conscription program, the IDF maintains approximately 176,500 active troops and an additional 445,000 reservists.{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.inss.org.il/upload/(FILE)1284986151.pdf |work=Middle East Military Balance |publisher=Institute for National Security Studies |location=Tel Aviv |title=Israel |date=20 September 2010 |accessdate=5 April 2012}} The nation's military relies heavily on [[Military equipment of Israel|high-tech weapons systems]] designed and manufactured in Israel as well as some foreign imports. Since 1967, the United States has been a particularly notable foreign contributor of [[Israel – United States military relations#Military aid|military aid to Israel]]: the US is expected to provide the country with $3.15 billion per year from 2013–2018.{{cite quick |web|url=http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/US-Israel/foreign_aid.html |title=U.S. Aid To Israel |publisher=Jewishvirtuallibrary.org |accessdate=29 September 2010}}{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/17/world/middleeast/17israel.html |work=The New York Times |title=Israel to Get $30 Billion in Military Aid From U.S |date=17 August 2007 |accessdate=23 September 2007 |last=Erlanger |first=Steven }} The [[Arrow (Israeli missile)|Arrow missile]] is one of the world's few operational [[anti-ballistic missile]] systems.{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.jpost.com/Israel/Article.aspx?id=56544 |newspaper=The Jerusalem Post |title='Arrow can fully protect against Iran' |last=Katz |first=Yaakov |date=30 March 2007 |accessdate=20 March 2012}} [[File:IAI-Lavi-B-2-hatzerim-2.jpg|thumb|left|[[IAI Lavi]], [[military technology]] demonstrator]] Since the [[Yom Kippur War]], Israel has developed a network of [[reconnaissance satellites]].{{cite quick |web |url=https://www.cia.gov/library/center-for-the-study-of-intelligence/kent-csi/vol44no5/html/v44i5a04p.htm |publisher=Central Intelligence Agency |title=Israel's Quest for Satellite Intelligence |last=Zorn |first=E. L. |date=8 May 2007 |accessdate=19 March 2012}} The success of the ''[[Ofeq]]'' program has made Israel one of seven countries capable of launching such satellites.{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.jpost.com/Israel/Article.aspx?id=64499 |newspaper=The Jerusalem Post |title=Analysis: Eyes in the sky |last=Katz |first=Yaakov |date=11 June 2007 |accessdate=20 March 2012}} Since its establishment, Israel has spent a significant portion of its gross domestic product on defense. In 1984, for example, the country spent 24%{{cite quick |document |url=http://www.thejerusalemfund.org/www.thejerusalemfund.org/carryover/pubs/20010130ib.html |publisher=The Jerusalem Fund |title=Israel's Defense Budget: The Business Side of War |last=Seitz |first=Charmaine |accessdate=16 September 2007 |date=30 January 2001 }} (first appeared in Information Brief No. 64) of its GDP on defense. By 2006, that figure had dropped to 7.3%. Israel is widely believed to [[Nuclear weapons and Israel|possess nuclear weapons]]{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.iaea.org/newscenter/transcripts/2004/alahram27072004.html |title=Transcript of the Director General´s Interview with Al-Ahram News |first=Mohamed |last=ElBaradei |authorlink=Mohamed ElBaradei |publisher=International Atomic Energy Agency |date=27 July 2004 |accessdate=20 March 2012}} as well as [[Israel and weapons of mass destruction|chemical and biological weapons of mass destruction]].{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.vaccines.mil/documents/library/proliferation.pdf |title=Proliferation of Weapons of Mass Destruction: Assessing the Risks |publisher=Office of Technology Assessment |month=August |year=1993 |accessdate=29 March 2012 |pages=65, 84}} Israel has not signed the [[Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons]]{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.un.org/en/conf/npt/2005/background.html |title=Background Information |date=27 May 2005 |work=2005 Review Conference of the Parties to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT) |publisher=United Nations |accessdate=9 April 2012}} and maintains a [[policy of deliberate ambiguity]] toward its nuclear capabilities.Ziv, Guy, "To Disclose or Not to Disclose: The Impact of Nuclear Ambiguity on Israeli Security," Israel Studies Forum, Vol. 22, No. 2 (Winter 2007): 76–94 Since the [[Gulf War]] in 1991, when Israel was attacked by Iraqi [[Scud missile]]s, all homes in Israel are required to have a reinforced security room impermeable to chemical and biological substances.{{cite quick |web |url=http://israelhomeowner.brinkster.net/Glossary.asp |title=Glossary |publisher=Israel Homeowner |accessdate=20 March 2012}} The IDF has also been deployed on humanitarian missions, usually involving rescue workers and medical personnel, along with relief workers and body identifiers from [[ZAKA]] and the [[Israel Police]]. After the [[2010 Haiti earthquake]], a rescue team was dispatched to Haiti, which consisted of 40 doctors, 20 nurses and rescue workers, and two rescue planes loaded with medical equipment and a field hospital with X-ray equipment, intensive care units, and operating rooms. Other recent recipients of aid include Japan (a medical team after the 2011 tsunami), Congo 2008, Sri Lanka 2005 (tsunami), India and El Salvador 2001 (earthquakes), Ethiopia 2000, Turkey 1998 (earthquake), Kosovo 1999 (refugees) and Rwanda 1994 (refugees).{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/Mashav+%E2%80%93+International+Development/Activities/Israeli+Humanitarian+Relief-+MASHAV+-+the+Israel+F.htm |title=Israeli Humanitarian Relief- MASHAV – the Israel F |publisher=Mfa.gov.il |accessdate=15 September 2011}} Israel is consistently rated very low in the [[Global Peace Index]], ranking 145th out of 153 nations for peacefulness in 2011.{{cite quick |web|author=Share this Email Twitter FacebookRankCountryScore |url=http://www.visionofhumanity.org/gpi-data/#/2011/scor |title=Rankings & Results « Vision of Humanity |publisher=Visionofhumanity.org |accessdate=15 September 2011}} ==Economy== {{Main|Economy of Israel}} [[File:Executive Airlines Gulfstream Aerospace G200 JBM.jpg|thumb|[[Gulfstream G200]] transcontinental business jet was designed and is currently produced for [[Gulfstream Aerospace]] by [[Israel Aerospace Industries|Israel Aircraft Industries (IAI)]]]] [[File:Tel Aviv P5280003.JPG|thumb|left|Aerial view of [[Tel Aviv Metropolitan Area|Tel Aviv Metropolitan Area (Gush Dan)]]]] Israel is considered one of the most advanced countries in Southwest Asia in economic and industrial development. In 2010, it joined the [[OECD]].{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.oecd.org/general/listofoecdmembercountries-ratificationoftheconventionontheoecd.htm |title=List of OECD Member countries - Ratification of the Convention on the OECD |publisher=Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development |accessdate=12 August 2012}} The country is ranked 3rd in the region on the [[World Bank]]'s [[Ease of Doing Business Index]]{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.doingbusiness.org/rankings |publisher=World Bank |title=Economy Rankings |work=Ease of Doing Business |accessdate=20 March 2012}} as well as in the [[World Economic Forum|World Economic Forum's]] [[Global Competitiveness Report]].{{cite quick |book |url=http://reports.weforum.org/global-competitiveness-2011-2012/ |title=The Global Competitiveness Report 2011-2012 |publisher=World Economic Forum |year=2011 |accessdate=20 March 2012 |isbn=978-92-95044-74-6}} It has the second-largest number of [[startup company|startup companies]] in the world (after the United States){{cite quick |book |title=Intellectual Capital for Communities: Nations, Regions, and Cities |last=Bounfour |first=Ahmed |coauthors=Edvinsson, Leif |year=2005 |publisher=Butterworth-Heinemann |isbn=978-0-7506-7773-8 |page=47 |ref=harv |unused_data=page=368}} and the largest number of [[NASDAQ]]-listed companies outside North America.{{cite quick |news |title=NASDAQ Appoints Asaf Homossany as New Director for Israel |date=6 February 2005 |newspaper=NASDAQ OMX Group |accessdate=21 March 2012 |url=http://ir.nasdaqomx.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=177065}} In 2010, Israel ranked 17th among of the world's most economically developed nations, according to [[International Institute for Management Development|IMD's World Competitiveness Yearbook]]. The Israeli economy was ranked first as the world's most durable economy in the face of crises, and was also ranked first in the rate of research and development center investments.{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3891801,00.html |title='Israel's economy most durable in face of crises', Ynet 20 May 2010 |publisher=Ynetnews.com |date=20 June 1995 |accessdate=29 September 2010}} The Bank of Israel was ranked first among central banks for its efficient functioning, up from the 8th place in 2009. Israel was also ranked as the worldwide leader in its supply of skilled manpower. The Bank of Israel holds $78 billion of [[List of countries by foreign-exchange reserves|foreign-exchange reserves]].{{cite quick |web|url=http://www.imf.org/external/np/sta/ir/IRProcessWeb/colist.aspx |title=Data Template on International Reserves and Foreign Currency Liquidity – Reporting Countries |publisher=Imf.org |date=5 January 2001 |accessdate=8 July 2010}} [[File:Dizengoff Center.jpg|thumb|Shops at the [[Dizengoff Center]], [[Tel Aviv]]]] Despite limited natural resources, intensive development of the [[Agriculture in Israel|agricultural]] and industrial sectors over the past decades has made Israel largely self-sufficient in food production, apart from grains and beef. Other major imports to Israel, totaling $47.8 billion in 2006, include [[fossil fuel]]s, raw materials, and military equipment. Leading exports include electronics, software, computerized systems, communications technology, medical equipment, [[pharmaceuticals]], fruits, chemicals, military technology, and [[diamond cutting|cut]] [[Diamond industry in Israel|diamonds]];{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4067275,00.html |title=Israeli exports: From $6M to $80B |newspaper=Ynetnews |date=13 May 2011}} in 2006, Israeli exports reached $42.86 billion, and by 2010 they had reached $80.5 billion a year. Israel is a leading country in the [[Solar power in Israel|development of solar energy]].{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/reportsfromabroad/parry/20070815.html |title=Looking to the sun |first=Tom |last=Parry |date=15 August 2007 |newspaper=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation}}{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=15503716 |title=Israel Pushes Solar Energy Technology |newspaper=NPR |first=Linda |last=Gradstein |authorlink=Linda Gradstein |date=22 October 2007}} Israel is a global leader in [[water conservation]] and [[geothermal power|geothermal energy]],{{cite quick |web |url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/jrep/access/1271587481.html?FMT=ABS |publisher=The Jerusalem Report |date=28 May 2007 |accessdate=20 March 2012 |title=A Hotter Holy Land |last=Ginsburg |first=Mitch}} and its development of cutting-edge technologies in software, communications and the life sciences have [[Silicon Wadi|evoked comparisons]] with [[Silicon Valley]].{{cite quick |news |title=Israel keen on IT tie-ups |date=10 January 2001 |newspaper=[[Business Line]] |url=http://www.hindu.com/businessline/2001/01/11/stories/151139ue.htm |accessdate=19 March 2012}}{{cite quick |news |title=Israel's technology industry: Punching above its weight |date=10 November 2005 |newspaper=The Economist |url=http://www.economist.com/node/5149411 |accessdate=20 March 2012}} According to the [[OECD]], Israel is also ranked 1st in the world in expenditure on [[Research and Development]] (R&D) as a percentage of GDP.{{cite quick |web|url=http://www.oecd-ilibrary.org/sites/factbook-2010-en/07/01/01/07-01-01-g1.html?contentType=&itemId=/content/chapter/factbook-2010-55-en&containerItemId=/content/serial/18147364&accessItemIds=&mimeType=text/html |title=OECD Factbook 2010: Economic, Environmental and Social Statistics |publisher=Oecd-ilibrary.org |accessdate=22 March 2011}} [[Intel]]{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.jpost.com/Business/BusinessNews/Article.aspx?id=52876 |newspaper=The Jerusalem Post |date=27 February 2007 |accessdate=20 March 2012 |title=Intel to expand Jerusalem R&D |last=Krawitz |first=Avi}} and [[Microsoft]]{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.microsoftrnd.co.il/about/leadership |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |accessdate=19 March 2012 |title=Microsoft Israel R&D center: Leadership |quote=Avi returned to Israel in 1991, and established the first Microsoft R&D Center outside the US...}} built their first overseas [[research and development]] centers in Israel, and other high-tech multi-national corporations, such as [[IBM]], [[Cisco Systems]], and [[Motorola]], have opened facilities in the country. In July 2007, U.S. billionaire [[Warren Buffett]]'s [[Berkshire Hathaway]] bought an Israeli company [[Iscar]], its first non-U.S. acquisition, for $4 billion.{{cite quick |web |title=Berkshire Announces Acquisition |work=New York Times |date=6 May 2006 |accessdate=15 May 2010 |url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C02E7DB1F3FF935A35756C0A9609C8B63 }} Since the 1970s, Israel has received military aid from the United States, as well as economic assistance in the form of loan guarantees, which now account for roughly half of Israel's [[external debt]]. Israel has one of the lowest external debts in the developed world, and is a net lender in terms of net external debt (the total value of assets vs. liabilities in debt instruments owed abroad), which {{As of|2011|lc=yes}} stood at a surplus of US$58.7 billion.{{cite quick |web |publisher=Bank of Israel |title=Israel's International Investment Position (IIP) |date=18 December 2011 |url=http://www.bankisrael.gov.il/press/eng/111218/111218m.htm}}{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.xe.com/news/2012-03-19%2007:21:00.0/2550205.htm |title=Israel net creditor level rises to $56.8 bln in 2011}} Days of [[working time]] in Israel are Sunday through Thursday (for 5 a days 'week'), or Friday (for 6 a days 'week'). In observance of ''[[Shabbat]]'', in places where Friday is a work day and the majority of population is Jewish, Friday is a "short day", usually lasting till 14:00 in the winter, or 16:00 in the summer. Several proposals have been raised to adjust the work week with the majority of the world, and make Sunday a non-working day, while extending working time of other days, and/or replacing Friday with Sunday as a work day .{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.themarker.com/career/1.1739743 |newspaper=The Marker |title=Instead of 4 work days: 6 optional days to be considered half day-outs |last=Koren |first=Orah |date=26 June 2012 |accessdate=26 June 2012}} (in Hebrew) ===Tourism=== {{Main|Tourism in Israel}} Tourism, especially [[religious tourism]], is an important industry in Israel, with the country's temperate climate, beaches, [[archaeology|archaeological]] and historical sites, and unique geography also drawing tourists. Israel's security problems have taken their toll on the industry, but the number of incoming tourists is on the rebound.{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.jpost.com/LandedPages/PrintArticle.aspx?id=71992 |newspaper=The Jerusalem Post |title=Tourist visits above pre-war level |last=Burstein |first=Nathan |date=14 August 2007 |accessdate=20 March 2012}} In 2008, over 3 million tourists visited Israel.{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/pope-confirms-holy-land-pilgrimage-1.271706 |title=Pope confirms Holy Land pilgrimage |newspaper=Haaretz |accessdate=20 March 2012}} Israel has the highest number of museums per capita in the world.{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.jfns.org/page.aspx?id=43769 |title=Interesting Facts About Israel |publisher=Jewish Federation of the North Shore |accessdate=20 March 2012}} ===Transport=== {{Main|Transport in Israel}} [[File:Ben Gurion duty free.jpg|thumb|170px|Duty Free at [[Ben Gurion International Airport]]|alt=A large hall, with tall round columns; dozens of people standing or walking, around an entrance in the left wall. The area around the entrance is partitioned for the most part from the rest of the hall.]] Israel has 18,096 kilometers (11,244 mi) of paved roads,{{cite quick |document |url=http://www.cbs.gov.il/shnaton60/st24_12.pdf |title=Roads(1)(2), By Length and Area |year=2008 |publisher=Israeli Central Bureau of Statistics |accessdate=5 February 2010 }} and 2.4 million motor vehicles.{{cite quick |document |url=http://www.cbs.gov.il/reader/newhodaot/hodaa_template.html?hodaa=200927133 |title=2008 – 2.4 Million motor vehicles in Israel |date=29 June 2009 |publisher=Israeli Central Bureau of Statistics |accessdate=5 February 2010 }} The number of motor vehicles per 1,000 persons was 324, relatively low with respect to developed countries. Israel has 5,715 buses on scheduled routes,{{cite quick |document |url=http://www.cbs.gov.il/shnaton60/st24_04.pdf |title=Bus Services on Scheduled Routes | year=2009 |publisher=Israeli Central Bureau of Statistics |accessdate=5 February 2010 }} operated by several carriers, the largest of which is [[Egged (company)|Egged]], serving most of the country. Railways stretch across 949 kilometers (590 mi) and are operated solely by government-owned [[Israel Railways]]{{cite quick |document |url=http://www.cbs.gov.il/shnaton60/st24_05.pdf |title=Israeli Railway Services | year=2009 | publisher=Israeli Central Bureau of Statistics |accessdate=5 February 2010 }} (All figures are for 2008). Following major investments beginning in the early-to-mid 1990s, the number of train passengers per year has grown from 2.5 million in 1990, to 35 million in 2008; railways are also used to transport 6.8 million tons of cargo, per year. Israel is served by two international airports, [[Ben Gurion International Airport]], the country's main hub for international air travel near [[Tel Aviv-Yafo]], [[Ovda Airport]] in the south, as well as several small domestic airports.{{cite quick |document |url=http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Economy/transport.html |title=Transportation in Israel |date=1 November 2001 |publisher=Jewish Virtual Library |accessdate=5 February 2010 |isbn=0-08-043448-7 }} Ben Gurion, Israel's largest airport, handled over 12.1 million passengers in 2010.{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.iaa.gov.il/Rashat/en-US/Airports/BenGurion/AbouttheAirport/Statistics |title=Official airport statistics for Ben Gurion Airport |publisher=IAA |date=25 May 2009 |accessdate=21 June 2011}} On the [[Mediterranean]] coast, [[Port of Haifa|Haifa Port]] is the country's oldest and largest port, while [[Port of Ashdod|Ashdod Port]] is one of the few deep water ports in the world built on the open sea. In addition to these, the smaller [[Port of Eilat]] is situated on the [[Red Sea]], and is used mainly for trading with Far East countries. ===Science and technology=== {{Main|Science and technology in Israel|List of Israeli universities and colleges}} [[File:Weizmann accelerator.jpg|thumb|150px|The [[particle accelerator]] at the [[Weizmann Institute of Science]], [[Rehovot]]|alt=A night-time image of a gray windowless tower, with an egg-shaped windowed observation deck on top. Next to it is a low building, grass, and many trees and bushes.]] Israel's eight public universities are subsidized by the state.{{cite quick |web |url=http://embassies.gov.il/delhi/Departments/Pages/Academic%20Affairs.aspx |title=Higher Education in Israel |accessdate=19 March 2012 |publisher=Embassy of Israel In India}} The [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]], Israel's oldest university, houses the [[Jewish National and University Library]], the world's largest repository of books on Jewish subjects.{{cite quick |document |url=http://www.jnul.huji.ac.il/eng/history.html |publisher=Jewish National and University Library |title=About the Library |accessdate=5 August 2007 }} The Hebrew University is consistently ranked among world's 100 top universities by the prestigious [[Academic Ranking of World Universities|ARWU]] academic ranking.{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.shanghairanking.com/Institution.jsp?param=The%20Hebrew%20University%20of%20Jerusalem |title=The Hebrew University of Jerusalem |publisher=Academic Ranking of World Universities |accessdate=21 March 2012 |year=2011}} Other major universities in the country include the [[Technion]], the [[Weizmann Institute of Science]], [[Tel Aviv University]] (TAU), [[Bar-Ilan University]], the [[University of Haifa]], [[Open University of Israel|The Open University]] and [[Ben-Gurion University of the Negev]]. Israel's seven research universities (excluding the Open University) are consistently ranked among top 500 in the world.{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.shanghairanking.com/Country2011Main.jsp?param=Israel |publisher=Academic Ranking of World Universities |title=Israel |accessdate=21 March 2012 |year=2011}} Israel has produced six Nobel Prize-winning scientists since 2002{{cite quick |document |url=http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/Israel+beyond+politics/Prof_Yonath_2009_Nobel_Prize_Chemistry_7-Oct-2009 |publisher=Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs |date=7 October 2009 |accessdate=8 February 2010|title=Prof. Ada Yonath awarded 2009 Nobel Prize in Chemistry }}{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/channels/sci-tech/others/once-ridiculed-israels-shechtman-wins-chemistry-nobel-atomic-mosaic-624 |title=Once 'ridiculed', Israel's Shechtman wins Chemistry Nobel for atomic mosaic}} and publishes among the most scientific papers per capita of any country in the world.{{cite quick |document |url=http://pubs.acs.org/cen/science/84/8448sci1.html |publisher=American Chemical Society |work=Chemical & Engineering News |title=Globalization Of Science Rolls On |pages=26–31 |date=27 November 2006 |last=Heylin |first=Michael |accessdate=21 August 2007 }}{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.jpost.com/Opinion/Op-EdContributors/Article.aspx?id=32635 |newspaper=The Jerusalem Post |last=Gordon |first=Evelyn |title=Kicking the global oil habit |accessdate=20 March 2012 |date=24 August 2006}} Israel has embraced [[solar energy]]; its engineers are on the cutting edge of solar energy technology and its solar companies work on projects around the world.{{cite quick |news |title=At the Zenith of Solar Energy |first=Neal |last=Sandler |url=http://www.businessweek.com/stories/2008-03-26/at-the-zenith-of-solar-energybusinessweek-business-news-stock-market-and-financial-advice |newspaper=Bloomberg Businessweek |date=26 March 2008 |accessdate=12 August 2012}} Over 90% of [[Solar power in Israel|Israeli homes use solar energy]] for hot water, the highest per capita in the world.{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.neaman.org.il/Neaman2011/Templates/ShowPage.asp?DBID=1&TMID=581&LNGID=1&FID=646&IID=7974 |title=Solar energy for the production of heat Summary and recommendations of the 4th assembly of the energy forum at SNI |last1=Grossman |first1=Gershon |last2=Ayalon |first2=Ofira |last3=Baron |first3=Yifaat |last4=Kauffman |first4=Debby |date= |work= |publisher=Samuel Neaman Institute for Advanced Studies in Science and Technology |accessdate=12 August 2012}}{{cite quick |web |last1=Del Chiaro |first1=Bernadette |last2=Telleen-Lawton |first2=Timothy |title=Solar Water Heating: How California Can Reduce Its Dependence on Natural Gas |publisher=Environment California |url=http://www.environmentcalifornia.org/reports/cae/solar-water-heating-how-california-can-reduce-its-dependence-natural-gas |accessdate=20 March 2012 |format=PDF}} According to government figures, the country saves 8% of its electricity consumption per year because of its solar energy use in heating.{{cite quick |web |url=http://roma.mfa.gov.il/mfm/Data/156237.pdf |title=Solar, what else?! |last=Berner |first=Joachim |month=January |year=2008 |work=Sun & Wind Energy |publisher=Israel Special |page=88 |format=PDF |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20110721141348/http://roma.mfa.gov.il/mfm/Data/156237.pdf |archivedate=21 July 2011 |accessdate=15 May 2010}} The high annual incident [[irradiance|solar irradiance]] at its geographic [[latitude]] creates ideal conditions for what is an internationally renowned solar research and development industry in the [[Negev Desert]]. [[File:Solar dish at Ben-Gurion National Solar Energy Center in Israel.jpg|thumb|170px|left|alt=A horizontal parabolic dish, with a triangular structure on its top.|The world's largest solar parabolic dish at the [[Ben-Gurion National Solar Energy Center]].{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.theregister.co.uk/2008/01/25/faiman_negev_solar_plan/ |title=Giant solar plants in Negev could power Israel's future |first=John |last=Lettice |newspaper=The Register |date=25 January 2008}}]] [[File:Shechtman.jpg|thumb|150px|Israel's most recent Nobel laureate: [[Dan Shechtman]] won the 2011 [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry]].{{cite quick |news |title=Iowa State, Ames Laboratory, Technion scientist wins Nobel Prize in Chemistry |url=http://archive.news.iastate.edu/news/2011/oct/dannynobel |newspaper=Iowa State University |date=5 October 2011 |accessdate=12 August 2012}}]] Israel is one of the world's technological leaders in water technology. In 2011, its water technology industry was worth around $2 billion a year with annual exports of products and services in the tens of millions of dollars. The ongoing shortage of water in the country has spurred innovation in [[water conservation]] techniques, and a substantial agricultural modernisation, [[drip irrigation]], was invented in Israel. Israel is also at the technological forefront of [[desalination]] and water recycling. The Ashkelon seawater reverse osmosis (SWRO) plant, the largest in the world, was voted 'Desalination Plant of the Year' in the Global Water Awards in 2006. Israel hosts an annual Water Technology Exhibition and Conference (WaTec) that attracts thousands of people from across the world.{{cite quick |web |title=What You Israelis Have Done With Water Tech is Simply Amazing |url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/149829#.TyrL2cWDvko |publisher=Arutz Sheva |accessdate=16 November 2011}}{{cite quick |web |title=Ashkelon, Israel |url=http://www.water-technology.net/projects/israel/ |publisher=water-technology.net}} By the end of 2013, 85 percent of the country's water consumption will be from reverse osmosis.{{Update after|2014}} As a result of innovations in [[reverse osmosis|reverse osmosis technology]], Israel is set to become a net exporter of water in the coming years.{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/12/06/us-israel-desalination-idUSTRE7B50V520111206 |title=Desalination plant could make Israel water exporter |newspaper=Reuters |location=Jerusalem |date=6 December 2011}} Israel has led the world in stem-cell research papers per capita since 2000.{{cite quick |news |title=Stem cell density highest in Israel |first=Ned |last=Stafford |url=http://www.the-scientist.com/?articles.view/articleNo/23830 |newspaper=The Scientist |date=21 March 2006 |accessdate=18 October 2012}} In addition, Israeli universities are among 100 top world universities in mathematics ([[Hebrew University of Jerusalem|Hebrew University]], [[Tel Aviv University|TAU]] and [[Technion]]), physics (TAU, Hebrew University and [[Weizmann Institute of Science]]), chemistry (Technion and Weizmann Institute of Science), computer science (Weizmann Institute of Science, Technion, Hebrew University, TAU and [[Bar-Ilan University|BIU]]) and economics (Hebrew University and TAU).{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.shanghairanking.com/ |title=Academic Ranking of World Universities |publisher=[[Academic Ranking of World Universities]] |accessdate=19 March 2012 |year=2011}} Israel has a modern electric car infrastructure involving a countrywide network of recharging stations to facilitate the charging and exchange of car batteries. It is thought that this will lower Israel's oil dependency and lower the fuel costs of hundreds of Israel's motorists that use cars powered only by electric batteries.{{cite quick |news | url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2066975,00.html | title=Will Israel's Electric Cars Change the World? |work=Time | accessdate=11 April 2012}}{{cite quick |web | url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/c0ef35cc-c06a-11df-8a81-00144feab49a.html#axzz1rkIhl5wn | title=Electric cars are all the rage in Israel |work=FT | accessdate=11 April 2012}}{{cite quick |web | url=http://www.haaretz.com/business/israel-to-keep-electric-car-recharging-fees-low-1.418128 | title=Israel to keep electric car recharging fees low | publisher=Haaretz | accessdate=11 April 2012}} The Israeli model is being studied by several countries and being implemented in Denmark and Australia.{{cite quick |web | url=http://www.jpost.com/JerusalemReport/Science/Article.aspx?ID=258744&R=R1 | title=Baby you can drive my electric car | publisher=Jpost | accessdate=11 April 2012}} In 2009 Israel was ranked 2nd among 20 top countries in space sciences by [[Thomson Reuters]] agency.{{cite quick |document |url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?sectioncode=26&storycode=408577&c=1 |publisher=The Times Higher Education supplemmentary|title=Top countries in space sciences |accessdate=8 October 2009 |date=8 October 2009 }} Since 1988 [[Israel Aerospace Industries]] have indigenously designed and built at least 13 commercial, research and spy satellites.{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.spacenews.com/military/091113-ofeq-8-nearing-launch-ofeq-9-stalled.html |title=Ofeq-8 Nearing Launch, Ofeq-9 Stalled |accessdate=20 March 2012 |date=13 November 2009 |newspaper=SpaceNews.com |first=Barbara |last=Opall-Rome}} Most were launched to orbit from Israeli air force base "[[Palmachim Airbase|Palmachim]]" by the [[Shavit]] space launch vehicle. Some of Israel's satellites are ranked among the world's most advanced space systems.{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2008/jan/21/iran.marktran |title=Israel launches new satellite to spy on Iran |accessdate=20 March 2012 |date=21 January 2008 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |first=Mark |last=Tran}} In 2003, [[Ilan Ramon]] became Israel's first astronaut, serving as payload specialist of [[STS-107]], the [[Space Shuttle Columbia disaster|fatal mission]] of the [[Space Shuttle Columbia|Space Shuttle ''Columbia'']]. ==Demographics== {{Main|Demographics of Israel}} [[File:Population of Israel.png|thumb|Comparison of the changes in percentages of the main religious group in Israel between the years 1949–2008]] In 2012, Israel's population was an estimated 7,933,200 people, of whom 5,978,600 are [[Israeli Jews|Jews]]. [[Arab citizens of Israel]] comprise 20.6% of the country's total population. Over the last decade, large numbers of migrant workers from Romania, Thailand, China, Africa and South America have settled in Israel. Exact figures are unknown, as many of them are living in the country illegally,{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.irinnews.org/Report/85270/ISRAEL-Crackdown-on-illegal-migrants-and-visa-violators |title=ISRAEL: Crackdown on illegal migrants and visa violators |newspaper=IRIN |date=14 July 2009}} but estimates run in the region of 203,000.Adriana Kemp, "Labour migration and racialisation: labour market mechanisms and labour migration control policies in Israel", ''Social Identities'' 10:2, 267–292, 2004 {{As of|2012|June}}, approximately 60,000 [[Illegal immigration from Africa to Israel|African migrants]] have entered Israel.{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/06/11/us-israel-africans-idUSBRE85A0VI20120611 |title=Israel rounds up African migrants for deportation |newspaper=[[Reuters]] |date=11 June 2012}} Retention of Israel's population since 1948 is about even or greater, when compared to other countries with mass immigration.{{cite quick |book |last= DellaPergola |first= Sergio |authorlink= Sergio DellaPergola|editor= Still Moving: Recent Jewish Migration in Comparative Perspective, Daniel J. Elazar and Morton Weinfeld eds. |title= 'The Global Context of Migration to Israel' |origyear= 2000 |edition= |series= |year= 2000|publisher=Transaction Publishers |location= New Brunswick, New Jersey |isbn= 1-56000-428-2 |pages= 13–60 |ref= harv}} Emigration from Israel ([[yerida]]) to other countries, primarily the United States and Canada, is described by demographers as modest,{{cite quick |journal | last = Herman | first = Pini | title = The Myth of the Israeli Expatriate | journal=[[Moment Magazine]] | volume = 8 |issue = 8 | pages = 62–63| date = 1 September 1983 | ref = harv}} but is often cited by Israeli government ministries as a major threat to Israel's future.{{cite quick |web |first=Eric |last=Gould |first2=Omer |last2=Moav |title=The Israeli Brain Drain |month=July |year=2006 |page=26 |location=Jerusalem |publisher=Shalem Center |url=http://www.shalem.org.il/FileServer/df4b061c96a6fbceb95026260cb4de8a.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=20 March 2012}}{{cite quick |news |last=Rettig Gur |first=Haviv |title=Officials to US to bring Israelis home |newspaper=The Jerusalem Post |date=6 April 2008 |url=http://www.jpost.com/Israel/Article.aspx?id=97254 |accessdate=20 March 2012}} {{As of|2009}}, over 300,000 Israeli citizens live in [[West Bank]] settlements{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.fmep.org/settlement_info/settlement-info-and-tables/stats-data/settlements-in-the-west-bank-1 |title=Settlements in the West Bank |accessdate=20 March 2012 |publisher=Foundation for Middle East Peace |work=Settlement Information}} such as [[Ma'ale Adumim]] and [[Ariel (city)|Ariel]], and communities that predated the establishment of the State but were re-established after the [[Six-Day War]], in cities such as [[Hebron]] and [[Gush Etzion]]. 18,000 Israelis live in [[Golan Heights]] settlements.{{cite quick |document |url=http://www.fmep.org/settlement_info/settlement-info-and-tables/stats-data/settlements-in-the-golan-heights |title=Settlements in the Golan Heights |accessdate=12 December 2007 |publisher=Foundation for Middle East Peace |work=Settlement Information }} In 2011, there were 250,000 Jews living in [[East Jerusalem]].{{cite quick |news |url=http://blogs.jpost.com/content/president-obama%E2%80%99s-hostility-israel-continues |title=President Obama’s hostility to Israel continues |accessdate=20 March 2012 |newspaper=The Jerusalem Post}} The total number of Israeli settlers is over 500,000 (6.5% of the Israeli population). Approximately 7,800 Israelis lived in settlements in the [[Gaza Strip]], until they were evacuated by the government as part of its 2005 [[Israel's unilateral disengagement plan|disengagement plan]].{{cite quick |document |url=http://www.fmep.org/settlement_info/settlement-info-and-tables/stats-data/settlements-in-the-gaza-strip-1 |title=Settlements in the Gaza Strip |accessdate=12 December 2007 |publisher=Foundation for Middle East Peace |work=Settlement Information }} Israel was established as a homeland for the [[Jewish people]] and is often referred to as a [[Jewish state]]. The country's [[Law of Return]] grants all Jews and those of Jewish lineage the right to [[Israeli nationality law|Israeli citizenship]].{{cite quick |document |url=http://www.knesset.gov.il/laws/special/eng/return.htm |publisher=Knesset |title=The Law of Return |accessdate=14 August 2007 }} Over three quarters, or 75.5%, of the population are Jews from a [[Jewish ethnic divisions|diversity of Jewish backgrounds]]. Around 4% of Israelis (300,000), ethnically defined as "others", are [[Russian immigration to Israel in the 1990s|Russian-descendants]] of Jewish origin or family who are not Jewish according to rabbinical law, but were eligible for Israeli citizenship under the Law of Return.{{cite quick |web | url=http://jppi.org.il/uploads/Jewish_Demographic_Policies.pdf | title=Jewish Demographic Policies | publisher=[[The Jewish People Policy Institute]] |year=2011 | author=DellaPergola, Sergio}}{{cite quick |web | url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/topic/Israel_(people).aspx | title=Israel (people) | publisher=Encyclopedia.com |year=2007}} Approximately 68% of [[Israeli Jews]] are [[Sabra (person)|Israeli-born]], 22% are immigrants from Europe and the Americas, and 10% are immigrants from Asia and Africa (including the [[Arab World]]).{{cite quick |web |url=http://www1.cbs.gov.il/shnaton56/st02_24.pdf |format=PDF|title=Jews and others, by origin, continent of birth and period of immigration |accessdate=8 April 2006 |first=Government of Israel |last=Central Bureau of Statistics }}{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.hsje.org/forcedmigration.htm |title=The Forced Migration of Jews From Arab Countries and Peace |first=Ada |last=Aharoni |publisher=Historical Society of Jews From Egypt |accessdate=29 March 2012}} [[Jewish exodus from Arab and Muslim countries|Jews who left or fled Arab and Muslim countries]] and their descendants, known as ''Mizrahi'' and ''Sephardi'' Jews,{{cite quick |web |url=http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/jss/summary/v015/15.1.goldberg.html |title=From Sephardi to Mizrahi and Back Again: Changing Meanings of "Sephardi" in Its Social Environments}} constitute approximately 50% of Jewish Israelis.{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2009/apr/03/israel-arab-jewish-mizrahi |title=The myth of the Mizrahim |work=The Guardian |date=3 April 2009}}{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/History/jewref.html |title=Jewish Refugees from Arab Countries |last=Shields |first=Jacqueline |publisher=Jewish Virtual Library |accessdate=26 April 2012}}{{cite quick |web |url=http://www.jewcy.com/post/missing_mizrahim |title= Missing Mizrahim}} Jews from Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union and their Israeli-born descendants, or ''Ashkenazi'' Jews, form most of the rest of the Jewish population. {{Largest cities of Israel}} ===Languages=== {{Main|Languages of Israel}} Israel has two official languages, [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] and [[Arabic language|Arabic]]. Hebrew is the primary language of the state and is spoken by the majority of the population, and Arabic is spoken by the Arab minority. Many Israelis communicate reasonably well in English, as many television programs are broadcast in this language and English is taught from the early grades in elementary school. As a country of [[aliyah|immigrants]], many languages can be heard on the streets. Due to mass immigration from the former Soviet Union and [[Aliyah from Ethiopia|Ethiopia]] (some 120,000 [[Beta Israel|Ethiopian Jews]] live in Israel),{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2009/07/16/us-israel-ethiopia-jews-sb-idUSTRE56F4ZY20090716 |title=Israel may admit 3,000 Ethiopia migrants if Jews |newspaper=Reuters |date=16 July 2009}} Russian and [[Amharic]] are widely spoken.{{cite quick |news |title=Israel's welcome for Ethiopian Jews wears thin |first=Bill |last=Meyer |url=http://www.cleveland.com/world/index.ssf/2008/08/israels_welcome_for_ethiopian.html |newspaper=The Plain Dealer |date=17 August 2008 |accessdate=1 October 2012}} Between 1990 and 1994, the [[Aliyah from the Commonwealth of Independent States in the 1990s|Russian immigration]] increased Israel's population by twelve percent.{{cite quick |journal |url=http://www.brown.edu/Departments/Economics/Papers/1996/pdfs/96-28.pdf |journal=The Quarterly Journal of Economics |month=November |year=2001 |title=The Impact of Mass Migration on the Israeli Labor Market |last=Friedberg |first=Rachel M. |page=1373 |issue=4 |doi=10.1162/003355301753265606 |volume=116 |ref=harv}} More than one million Russian-speaking immigrants arrived in Israel from the former Soviet Union states between 1990 and 2004.{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/study-soviet-immigrants-outperform-israeli-students-1.238970 |title=Study: Soviet immigrants outperform Israeli students |newspaper=Haaretz |date=10 February 2008}} French is spoken by around 700,000 Israelis,{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4156781,00.html |title=French radio station RFI makes aliyah |newspaper=Ynetnews |date=5 December 2011}} mostly originating from France and North Africa (see [[Maghrebi Jews]]). ===Religion=== {{Main|Religion in Israel}} [[File:Temple Mount Western Wall on Shabbat by David Shankbone.jpg|thumb|160px|The [[Western Wall]] and the [[Dome of the Rock]], Jerusalem|alt=A large open area with hundreds of people, bounded by old stone walls. Beyond it are houses and a few trees, to the right is a mosque with large golden dome, and to the left – a minaret.]] [[File:Ruins of the Ancient Synagogue at Bar'am.jpg|left|thumb|160px|The ancient synagogue of [[Kfar Bar'am]]Judaism in late antiquity, Jacob Neusner, Bertold Spuler, Hady R Idris, BRILL, 2001, p. 155Art and Judaism in the Greco-Roman world: toward a new Jewish archaeology, Steven Fine, Cambridge University Press, 2005, pp. 13–14]] [[File:Golgotha (Church of the Holy Sepulchre).jpg|thumb|upright|160px|The [[Church of the Holy Sepulchre]], venerated by Christians as the site of the [[Crucifixion]] of Jesus.{{cite quick |Catholic Encyclopedia| wstitle=Holy Sepulchre| title =Holy Sepulchre| first =Arthur .L.| last = McMahon| accessdate =2 February 2009}}]] [[File:Archives and the port.jpg|thumb|160px|left|[[Bahá'í World Centre buildings#International Archives|International Bahá'í Archives building at Bahá'í World Centre]], overlooking the [[Shrine of the Báb]] and the [[Port of Haifa]].]] Israel and the [[Palestinian territories]] comprise the major part of the [[Holy Land]], a region of significant importances to all [[Abrahamic religions]] – Jews, Christians, Muslims and [[Baha'is]]. The religious affiliation of [[Israeli Jews]] varies widely: a social survey for those over the age of 20 indicates that 55% say they are "traditional", while 20% consider themselves "secular Jews", 17% define themselves as "[[Religious Zionism|Religious Zionists]]"; 8% define themselves as "[[Haredi Judaism|Haredi]] Jews".{{cite quick |document |url=http://www.jcpa.org/dje/articles2/relinisr-consensus.htm |title=Religion in Israel: A Consensus for Jewish Tradition |last=Elazar |first=Daniel J. |publisher=Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs |accessdate=6 September 2007 }} While the ultra-Orthodox, or Haredim, represented only 5% of Israel's population in 1990,{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2010/0709/The-other-Israeli-conflict-with-itself |title=The other Israeli conflict: with itself |newspaper=The Christian Science Monitor |date=9 July 2010}} they are expected to represent more than one-fifth of Israel's Jewish population by 2028.{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/opinion/at-the-edge-of-the-abyss-1.3538 |title=At the edge of the abyss |newspaper=Haaretz |date=24 November 2009}} Making up 16% of the population, Muslims constitute Israel's largest religious minority. About 2% of the population are Christian and 1.5% are [[Druze]].{{cite quick |web |url=http://www1.cbs.gov.il/shnaton56/st02_01.pdf |title=Population, by religion and population group |accessdate=6 August 2007 |first=Government of Israel |last=Central Bureau of Statistics |format=PDF| ref=harv}} The Christian population primarily comprises [[Arab Christians]], but also includes post-Soviet immigrants and the Foreign Laborers of multinational origins and followers of [[Messianic Judaism]], considered by most Christians and Jews to be a form of Christianity.{{cite quick |news |title=Israel's Christian population numbers 148,000 as of Christmas Eve |first=Moti |last=Bassok |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/israel-s-christian-population-numbers-148-000-as-of-christmas-eve-1.208151 |newspaper=Haaretz |date=25 December 2006 |accessdate=26 April 2012}} Members of many other religious groups, including [[Buddhism|Buddhists]] and [[Hindu]]s, maintain a presence in Israel, albeit in small numbers.{{cite quick |document |url=http://www.cbs.gov.il/shnaton53/st_eng02.pdf |format=PDF |title=National Population Estimates |accessdate=6 August 2007 |page=27 |publisher=Central Bureau of Statistics }} Out of more than one million immigrants from the former [[Russian immigration to Israel in the 1990s|Soviet Union]] in Israel, about 300,000 are considered not Jewish by the Orthodox rabbinate.{{cite quick |news |url=http://www.economist.com/node/15675691 |title=Israel's disputatious Avigdor Lieberman: Can the coalition hold together?
